titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Nablus Arabic

div.p: Nablus lies in a fertile valley between Mount Gerizim (Ǧabal aṭ-Ṭūr) and Mount Ebal (Ǧabal ˁAybāl). It was founded under the Roman emperor Vespasian in 72 CE and named Flavia Neapolis. The name “Nablus” is a corrupted form of “Neapolis”. In Hebrew, it is called Shechem, because of an erroneous association of Nablus with the ancient Canaanite city of this name.

It is one of the biggest cities in the West Bank and a centre of commerce and culture. It used to rely on agricultural production from its hinterlands, particularly olive oil, from which it famously produced soap. It was the main city of a relatively autonomous area and a centre of resistance to the British Mandate authorities and the Israeli occupation, respectively. Due to the role it played in both intifadas, it was largely cut off from the surrounding villages by checkpoints, thus impeding trade and hindering economic development. Nablus is often referred to as Ǧabal an-Nār, the “mountain of fire”. This is understood to be a reference to its rebelliousness.

Mount Gerizim is the religious centre of a Samaritan minority. Although their religious belief is a branch of Judaism, the political affiliation of Nablus’ Samaritans is mostly with the West Bank Arabs, but they strive to keep a neutral position in the conflict. There are also Samaritans who live in Holon, near Tel Aviv. The Samaritans have their own distinct dialect and do not intermarry with the rest of Nablus’ population, but sometimes with the Jewish population of Israel.
Historically, trade relations in the region ran East-West in the wider area, and Nablus shares close familial relations (and linguistic ties) with as-Salt and Amman, as attested by Al-Wer 2007.

Several bits and pieces of information about the dialect of Nablus seem to be common knowledge among Palestinians, and it is described in several sources as being distinctively different from other dialects.

Bauer 1926 (first published 1898) provides general information on Palestinian Arabic. Bergsträsser 1915 provides some information on Nablus, but that old Arabic q and k should have merged into k as described by Bergsträsser is contested by Arnold 2013, who believes this account indicates an unreliable source for Bergsträsser’s data. Arnold himself heavily relies on the master’s thesis by Annuri 1979 in his comparative description of the Samaritan and Muslim majority dialect of Nablus, for which he only conducted fieldwork on the former. Other characteristic features Arnold describes are a strong final imāla ā > e and the personal pronoun 1st pers. sing. ʾani.

Abdel Jawad 1987 holds that people who use the voiceless uvular plosive [q] as a reflex of standard [q] are commonly marked as “Nabulsi”, as this is a feature that used to distinguish it from other urban Levantine dialects. However, [q] tends to be abandoned by younger generations in favour of the glottal stop [ʔ], and seems to have disappeared almost entirely, save for the speech of older and uneducated speakers who use [q] categorically. As Abdel-Jawad 1987 notes, this is despite the fact that Nablus is a regional centre and could function as a reference point for a regional prestigious variety. The thesis of the [q] reflex of [q] is in accordance with Arnold.
Apart from that, Nablus shows a strong Damascene influence not only culturally – it is often called “Little Damascus” – but also linguistically. This is especially true for the Samaritan minority.

Even though Nabulsi is apparently such a characteristic dialect, comprehensive descriptions do not exist, apart from Annuri’s unpublished master’s thesis. The Samaritan dialect, however, is described by Stenhouse 1989 and characterized by a strong final imāla. Arnold 2006, whose source is an older Samaritan woman who grew up in Holon and has lived in Nablus for some time, also provides texts and a description, in addition to Arnold 2003 dealing exclusively with the Samaritans of Holon. The aforementioned work by Arnold 2013 deals with the Samaritan dialect, but also mentions characteristics of the general Nablus dialect.
The dialect of Nablus has played an important role in the formation of more recently developed dialects, namely that of Amman, as attested by Herin 2019.
